Subject: Automating parameter setting in evolutionary algorithms
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211599040; y=_hgHr47El2EBNWIuGPra47hu02h3OAFTGVQ9KHaI0FeqFvUfsR5n

Hello all-

There are frequently conversations on this list about what para=
meter
settings to use for evolutionary runs.

At the CEC conference this ye=
ar I saw a presentation of a paper which
reviews and compares different alg=
orithms for automating the
setting of parameters for evolutionary algorithm=
s. They report that the best
algorithms for setting experimental parameters=
 greatly improve performance
vs. humans picking their own values.

It might=
 be interesting to turn the best in class algorithm loose on NEAT or
HyperN=
EAT, and see what parameters are chosen (and then see how much these
result=
s generalize to different problem domains). At a minimum, these
algorithms =
may help you if you are looking to truly optimize whatever
problem you are =
working on.

Comparing Parameter Tuning Methods for Evolutionary Algorithms=
. Smit and
Eiben. CEC 2009.

Abstract:
Tuning the parameters of an evolutio=
nary algorithm (EA) to a given problem
at hand is essential for good algori=
thm performance. Optimizing parameter
values is, however, a non-trivial pro=
blem, beyond the limits of human
problem solving. In this light it is odd t=
hat no parameter tuning algorithms
are used widely in evolutionary computin=
g. This paper is meant to be
stepping stone towards a better practice by di=
scussing the most important
issues related to tuning EA parameters, describ=
ing a number of existing
tuning methods, and presenting a modest experiment=
al comparison among them.
The paper is concluded by suggestions for future =
research =E2=80=B9 hopefully
inspiring fellow researchers for further work
=

PS. I can send you the paper if you email me.

PPS. I talked to A. E. Eibe=
n, one of the authors, about the fact that
automating
the process seems on =
the surface to contradict my PLoS Computational Biology
paper result that e=
volution is
bad at managing its own parameters. While we had a very long ch=
at about
That result in general, which I will not recount, the apparent con=
tradiction
is resolved when
one realizes that here evolution is not managin=
g its own parameters during
the run, but only choosing good settings to hav=
e fixed throughout the run.


Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Mi=
chigan State University
